Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Six themmed familiar and Party games.
All different but all tasty, all good and all healthy.

'Presto!' is a game of speed and visual acuity in which we will compete to be the first to get the ingredients of the recipe, even taking them away from rivals.

'Pizza Crush' is a spatial vision game in which we will try to get the ingredients for our recipe from a common matrix that will vary with each player's decisions.

In 'Mamma mia!' we will have to be the fastest in assembling the pizza slice requested by customers.

At 'Another slice, please' we will force our luck to be the first to deliver 5 correct orders to customers.

'Oh sole mio!' encourages us to collect sets of ingredients and complete orders of different value to be the winner.

Finally, 'La ricetta de la nonna' will force us to squeeze our brain to remember grandmother's mythical pizza recipe amidst the constant sway of ingredients.

The 6 games that make up PIZZA EXPRESS have a more complex version so that children and adults never get bored and always find a challenge to face.
Alien: USCSS Nostromo is based on the movie Alien.
Macao is a game.

Maracaibo, the new strategy game for 2-4 players by Alexander Pfister, is set in the Caribbean during the 17th century. The players try to increase their influence in three nations in four rounds with a play time of 40 minutes per player.
The players sail on a round course through the Caribbean. E.g., you have city tiles where you are able to perform various actions or deliver goods to. One special feature is an implemented quest mode over more and various tiles, which tells the player, who chase after it, a little story. 
As a player, you move with your ship around the course, managing it by using cards like in other games from Alexander Pfister.

—revised user summary

Apex Portal presents Lost Plateau, inspired by the 1912 classic novel, The Lost World, by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. On this secret plateau, dinosaurs roam a land of volcanoes and treacherous cliffs. Expeditions navigate stampeding dinosaurs while chasing eggs.

Dinosaurs! At Apex Portal we love primal physical mechanics. We evolved Lost Plateau for over 10 years. This design strived for 2 goals to produce primal tension. First, to have dinosaurs with an elegant set of behaviors (stampede, defensive facing, double dino combinations) to capture opposing dinosaurs. Second, to balance the influence of the 2 entities, the expedition and the dinosaur, so both are always in consideration for their way of scoring and interacting between each other. You control a herd and an expedition. The dino behaviors are truly predatorial for a fun tactical level game. When will your expedition feel safe to make a run the gauntlet of opposing dinos for the eggs? That question and getting your herd to the high ground is the strategy side of the game.

Game Description
 This is a physical primal game.
 A player turn is 2 actions – may do the same action twice.
Move Expedition Action – Pick up and deliver eggs to the Safe Camps. Using the in-game Trail Blaze expansion allows unlimited movement on established trails that can be co-developed between competitors.
Move Dinosaur Action – Dinos stampede dinos and opposing expeditions. The dino is moved and then given facing to prevent stampede from one direction. If both actions are Move Dino then sly double dino stampedes appear out of the mist! This encourages dinos to stay within reach of herd mates and maximizes true predator mind set – you always see opportunity, but often don't see the other herd coming after you.

Winning the game - Score 6 total eggs and/or dino captures.

Two unique team versions for 4 to 6 player. Can play as team mates or as competing “herd mates”. Herd mates both control and share the points scored by their herd, but don't share in egg scoring. The team games are also unique for the speed of play. A 6 player game runs!

Trail Blaze Expansion. The in-game expansion adds a 3rd action, for experienced gamers. Each player or team has 20 blazes to use. The action is the placing of 5 blazes on any spaces of the board. The Expeditions may move into any space that is adjacent and has at least 2 Blazes and at least one is of the player's color. The Trail Blaze markers make it so players have intense interaction between dinos and expeditions and adds co-opetition to jump in on other player's trails.

—description from the publisher

Each player in Croco Rider has twelve discs that they lay out in a circle on their half of the game board. These discs have values from 1 to 6 and from -1 to -6. The game board shows five crocodiles on it, with the crocodiles having 3-7 spaces on them.

To start the game, a player places one of their discs on an empty crocodile space. The next player chooses a disc and places it on an empty space, whether on the same crocodile or a different one. On each subsequent turn, a player can play either disc from the open end of their circle.

When a crocodile has two face-up discs on it, whether of the same or different colors, one of those discs is turned face down. If both discs are positive or negative, the disc closer to the crocodile's head wins and the other one is turned face down; if one disc is positive and the other negative, then the disc closer to the tail wins.

Once all the pieces have been placed, the game ends. Whoever has their disc face up on a crocodile scores points for that disc, with the value being equal to the number on the disc (1-6) multiplied by the position of the disc on the crocodile from the tail forward. If the crocodile has four spaces, for example, and you have a 3 near the crocodile's head, then you score 12 points for it (3 x 4 for the fourth space on the crocodile). Whoever has the higher score wins.

The game board in Anacund is composed of 17 wooden slats; fifteen of these slats have an ideogram at either end, with these ideograms representing the numbers 1-6. Shuffle these slats, then place them in a row, then place the remaining two slats (each with three ideograms) on either end to create a single path of 36 spaces. One of these spaces is colored red and dubbed the "bonus square". Each player takes 18 of the double-sided tokens, then places them in three groups of six, with their color face up.

On a turn, you must place three of your tokens on the game board. The space that you place a token on must equal the number of tokens in the group before you placed that token. Thus, at the start of the game, you take a token from a group of six tokens, then place that token on a 6 space. Your next token must be placed on a 5 (if taken from the same group) or a 6 (if taken from one of your remaining two groups).

If after placing a token, you have sandwiched one or more of the opponent's tokens, those opposing tokens are flipped over and placed next to the spaces they once occupied. These spaces cannot be played in again. If you would create a sandwich with yourself in the middle, then your own pieces are captured — unless you have simultaneously sandwiched the opponent at the same time, in which case you capture them instead.

Once all the pieces have been placed, players tally their scores. Each piece showing your color, whether on the board or next to it, is worth 1 point; whoever has a piece on or next to the bonus space scores 5 points. Whoever has the higher score wins.

Abyss Conspiracy, which is not necessarily the game's final name, is a card game set in the world of Abyss.

The card deck in the game consists of cards in five colors, with twelve of each color and cards numbered 0-6. Each player in the game drafts cards and builds a reverse pyramid, starting with a row of five cards, then placing four cards in a row below that, then three under that, etc.

On a turn, you can draw 1-3 cards from the deck, choose one of those cards and add it to your current row, then place any remaining cards grouped by color near the deck; alternatively, you can pick up all the cards of a color next to the deck and add them to your current row.

As soon as the cards in your rows show two matching keys or three different keys, you take either the revealed location card or the top card of the location deck, and place it on the lattermost card with a key. Location cards increase the value of a card and sometimes have special powers. Some cards feature pearls, and when you have as many or more pearls as whoever has the pearl majority card, you take this card from them.

The game ends as soon as someone finishes their pyramid, then all players score their points. For each color, you score points equal to the largest valued card in your pyramid. Additionally, for each color, you look at the largest grouping of cards in your pyramid and you score 3 points for each of those cards. Whoever held the pearl majority card at game's end scores 5 points for it. Whoever has the highest score wins.

Tyr is a fickle god, creating in his image and then forsaking his children when their reflection does not paint him favorably. Among all of the creators, Tyr’s universe is the most volatile, competitive, and in turn, the most interesting. The other divinities searched and have found a way to hide from Tyr’s Judge, each leaving small traces of themselves in his world. This has not gone unnoticed; Tyr allows their interference to enhance his Trials and test the mettle of his creations. Savor your favor, it may not last long.
 Raid Boss: Incarnate is a 4-player cooperative boss battle designed to feel like an MMORPG dungeon encounter with all of the teamwork, strategy, and collaboration, but none of the endless grinding!

You control a Hero with a mechanically distinct and heavily themed set of abilities. Each Hero has an Assist that can be used at ANY time -- including other players’ turns! Gather your team to face off against stalwart, quirky, and skill-testing Bosses that come equipped with their own special deck of cards. 
Raid Boss has flexibility that allows you to devise incredibly clever skill sequences. Game-ending threats soon become trivial as you experiment and gain experience, allowing you to tackle devious and puzzle-like advanced Bosses.

There are 12 Heroes and 6 Bosses, each lavishly illustrated, giving you a wealth of content and variety of challenges.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
Have you ever wondered what comes after the zombie apocalypse? What might society look like in a world where the undead are a threat to the living, but where their presence is just an aspect of life?

What We Became is a board game for 4 to 8 players that explores these questions. Players take on the role of community leaders, each of them with a specific vision of what their society could be. They will need to work together to keep the community safe, erect new buildings, and instill new ways of doing things among the populace, but always remembering that none of the other players shares their exact vision.

What We Became is highly competitive, but the environment presents enough of a threat that players will need to negotiate and work together with adversaries to stay alive, all while trying to outmaneuver them to come out ahead. At the end of each game, you will realize that a story has been told about the ups, downs, successes, and failures of a community decades after the world as we know it has ceased to exist.

—description from the publisher

item.description:
As an engineer in Alien Comms you are here to establish a new Telecommunications Station on a small satellite in a galaxy far away.

In Alien Comms, each turn you flip cards from three piles to make three different action sets from which every player chooses one. On one side you will find an Alien faction and an antenna model; on the other side, an Alien extension number and a energy adapter. You mark the chosen Alien Extension on it´s Alien faction and the Antenna Model on their tracks. Then you draw the antenna model and the energy adapter on an empty spot on your satellite.

But, what am I going to do with all of these antennas? Well... connect them to the Astronomic Entities, of course! There might be others trying to do the same as you and in these times it is known that nobody will buy the "second" quickest connection... Since actions are taken at the same time, all players can claim their connection to an Astronomic Entities on the same turn, but not on the next ¡so be quick to claim them before it is too late!

Each day a new galaxy is discovered and many are waiting to be the first ones to establish a contact there... Will you be the next?

—description from the designer
